ENGLISH: The Arrival of Fingolfin

The journey has been long and costly, you and followers wearied beyond measure. Each kinsman lost to the bleak wastes of Araman, however, stoked our wrath.  Your half-brother brought your folk into kinslaying and banishment, finally abandoning them by burning the ships meant to bear them to the East.  By forcing you to choose between a disgraceful return to Tirion or a treacherous march across the Helcaraxë, he declared himself an enemy of the folk of Fingolfin. While your purpose is still to avenge your father Finwë by overthrowing Morgoth in Angband, this crime of Fëanor's weighs heavily upon the hearts of your people.\n\nAt the first rising of the Sun, you take your first steps upon the Hither Lands of Middle-Earth.
We must find my treacherous half-brother.
The Battle of Lammoth

The Dark Lord, it seems, is aware of our arrival and your intention to dethrone him.\n\nThe scouts returning from Lammoth report that a force has appeared to cut us off and destroy our people!  A teeming host of thousands of orkish warriors, led by a half-demon Boldog-lord, are but days away from your encampment.
We can expect no aid. Prepare for battle!
The Battle of Lammoth

The day is yours, as the hollow children of Morgoth are no match for the power and grace of the Eldar.  But your folk are not without losses, as you discover to your horror.  Argon, your youngest son, fought bravely in leading a charge to the orkish lines, hewing a path through the foes and killing the orc-demon captain.  Alas, he now lies dead on the cold field of Lammoth.
Morgoth, you will pay for this!
Fëanor, you will pay for this!

ENGLISH: The Fate of the Ñoldor

As you have tended to be plagued with nightmares the past centuries, you spend sleepless nights pondering the fate of the Ñoldor. The moon was a sign of hope, appearing the eve of your arrival on the fair lands of Middle-Earth.  But this hope proved tainted by lies and treachery, which spread still throughout Middle-Earth. Perhaps the Ñoldor deserve to endure this misery - after all, Mandos voices the mind of Eru, and it was he who cursed them..

ENGLISH: The Ruin of the Ñoldor

The siege of Angband is broken, the long war lost! Scattered reports have reached you - of friends and their entire hosts of bannermen dead, burned alive by the fires of Thangorodrim.  The lands of Beleriand have been tainted and the light of the sun blotted out by the choking ash of Dor Daedeloth.  The ruin of the Ñoldor is nigh, their realms laid bare for the ravages of Morgoth's hosts.  All that remains is vengeance. And perhaps, redemption.

The Fall of Fingolfin

The King has fallen, and the tale of his end brings shock and sorrow to the hearts of all Ñoldor, even in the midst of the Bragollach.\n\nIn wrath and anguish, it is said, Fingolfin rode alone to the gates of Angband, a terrible figure of glory and might reminiscent of the Great Rider Oromë.  It was there in the shadow of the Thangorodrim that Fingolfin met his fate, in single combat with the fallen Vala Morgoth himself.  Before he was broken by the Hammer of the Underworld and interred beneath a cairn by Thorondor, the valiant lord is said to have wounded the Dark Lord seven times.

The High King in Hithlum

You are Fingolfin, the greatest Ñoldorin lord in Beleriand. Half-brother to Fëanor, the High Kingship fell to you when Maedhros abdicated to mend the feud between the two great houses. Your house reigns in Hithlum still, over a subject people throughout Dor-Lomin and Mithrim. The house of the late Fëanor the Great rules over independent realms of Eastern Beleriand, as it seems that Maedhros's prideful (and perhaps resentful) brothers are unwilling to reign as vassals. You should be wary, High King, of their ambition, but above all you must keep the watch on Angband. If Morgoth's hosts are allowed once more to roam Beleriand freely, then the age of Elves in Middle-Earth will surely yield to one of orcs and demons.

ENGLISH: A Feast of Reuniting

If the past twenty years have been portentous, the future of Beleriand is grim. Tensions between the hosts of the Noldor, Nandor, Avari, and Sindar threaten to tear elf-kind apart even further during this time of direst peril. The world of the firstborn needs a strong gesture towards unity and common cause against the Dark Lord - a diplomatic council held under the pretense of celebration at the reuniting of long lost kindreds. You must send emissaries to all the great elf-realms west of the Ered Luin, to meet at a commonly revered location. Here we can settle our grievances and perhaps rescue the children of Ilúvatar from the brink of annihilation.

#CODE: # The feast of Mereth Aderthad at Ivrin

ENGLISH: Mareth Aderthad

The great Feast of Reuniting has begun at the shores of Ivrin's well. Pavilions are pitched far across the fields and forests near the shorelines of the pristine pool, wherein pilgrims bathe to cleanse themselves. The many high lords sent from the realms of Beleriand to this meeting have met at a great banquet, where poetry is recited and music sung in several langauges. It has become clear through your interactions with the peoples here that the once unified Eldar have fragmented into a colorful multitude of different races. Embracing this diversity, you emphasize the unity of purpose all firstborn share - for peace and prosperity in Beleriand, and resistance against the tyranny of the Dark Lord. You sway the ambassadors with tales of Dor-Daedeloth, instilling in them fear of that terrible northern foe that they know all too little of. As the days of the feast slow to a closure, it becomes clear that that there has been a true understanding between most of the elf-lords present. We are friends, not foes, and our common kinship should outweigh any superficial differences. We are all of One creator, after all, and are beset by those who would see His creation marred further.
And with Morgoth held at bay, we can hope now that a Long Peace reigns in Beleriand.
